Abstract
Practical deliberation can be thought of as consisting of two stages: we think about our options and then (if all goes well) choose the option we consider best. Failures of practical rationality are typically associated with the second stage. In this talk, I consider whether the first stage â thinking of our options â falls within the scope of rational evaluation. Recently, some have argued that agents may be practically irrational for excluding particular options from consideration when these options are especially well-aligned with their values and reasons (Jeppsson, 2018). Others argue that, since option generation is spontaneous and sub-personal, the only rationally evaluable aspect at this stage is how long an agent spends thinking about their options (Wedgwood, 2017). I canvass a third possibility: the process of thinking about our options is structured by the exercise of attentional capacities and competence. This suggests that the normativity of attention is importantly intertwined with the normativity of practical rationality.

Title:
Credence without Probability
Abstract:
I develop the Typicality Principle of Expectations (TPE), a novel rationality principle that links typicality-based probabilistic explanations with expectations about the future. I argue that TPE offers a more coherent foundation in the context of typicality-based probabilistic explanations for expectations than traditional rationality principles, including Cournot's Principle, Locke's Principle of Proportionality and Lewis's Principal Principle. The framework of the TPE will ultimately reject a fundamental assumption about probability, namely, its Janus-faced dual nature, as representing objective chance and credences. Thus, I advocate a monistic account of probability: probabilities reflect purely statistical patterns and do not directly map to credences.
